Award.AwardTitle: A Corpus-Based Sociolinguistic Study of Spanish in the Metro-Boston Area

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Over 40 million Americans speak Spanish. This figure eclipses the individual populations of every country in Latin America except Mexico and Colombia, and it is roughly equivalent to the current population of Spain. Of the estimated 34 million Americans over five years old who speak Spanish at home, 25 million also report speaking English 'well' (6.4 million) or 'very well' (18.8 million). By 2050, the number of Americans who self-identify as Hispanic is likely to surpass 130 million. In broad strokes, these facts paint a clear picture: Spanish is, and will continue to be, a defining element of our national linguistic identity. In order to better understand the current role of Spanish in American life, and in order to predict how it may evolve in the future, it is essential to study the linguistic effects of two forces shaping its use today. First, Spanish and English are spoken alongside each other on a massive scale. Second, the many different varieties of the Spanish language found across the globe are present in a condensed setting in the United States. This means that individuals who might rarely interact with speakers outside of their own communities in Latin America are, throughout the U.S., in frequent contact with speakers whose national and regional origins are different from their own.

This project studies the outcomes of these two kinds of linguistic contact (known as language and dialect contact, respectively) among Spanish speaking residents of Boston, MA. The analysis focuses on two linguistic features as they occur in spontaneous speech: (1) subject pronouns (the Spanish equivalent of words like 'I', 'you', and 'we') and (2) the acoustic properties of the speech sound 's'. Patterns of variation in these features are akin to linguistic fingerprints, uniquely relatable to individuals and communities. Current research on Spanish in other American locales indicates that these features are, unlike fingerprints, susceptible to change. Tracking and understanding the nature of such change bears directly on a host of issues relevant to Spanish in the United States as well as linguists' general understanding of contact-induced language change. These include the maintenance of Spanish across immigrant generations, the potential influence of English on the grammatical structure of Spanish and vice versa, the persistence or erosion of dialect differences in contact situations, and the timescale of language change. In addition to speech data, the project also collects and analyzes speakers' personal linguistic histories. These include their descriptions of when, how, and with whom they acquired and use Spanish as well as their attitudes towards and use of English in their daily lives. Together these data will create a rich profile of Spanish in Boston that promises to increase understanding of how Spanish is used in the United States, particularly in the large urban areas in which most Americans live.

POR.DRECONTENT:
1. Overview

This study examined the linguistic behavior of Spanish-speaking residents of Boston, MA. The goals of the study included (1) creating a corpus of recorded spontaneous speech that reflected the linguistic diversity of Boston’s Spanish-speaking community, (2) tracking patterns of intergenerational stability and/or change in the ways Spanish is spoken and used by Bostonians, and (3) using the study’s findings to increase understanding of Spanish in the urban U.S. as well as in the nation as a whole.

2. Data

Over the course of the project, the study’s research team conducted interviews with 192 speakers, recording spontaneous speech data suitable for in-depth acoustic and quantitative analysis. In addition, all participants completed an extensive demographic and linguistic questionnaire, resulting in detailed sociolinguistic profiles for each of the study’s participants. The speech data were transcribed and measured acoustically. Several additional linguistic features were also coded and prepared for quantitative analysis. The linguistic data were integrated with the sociodemographic, attitudinal, and usage data collected from the questionnaire.

3. Results

Analysis of the data produced several findings: (1) Among Spanish-speaking immigrants and their Boston-born children, frequency of use of Spanish decreases as U.S. life experience increases, i.e., participants demonstrated a clear pattern of what is known to linguists as language shift; (2) Reduction in the daily use of Spanish occurred alongside increased use of English, in both private domains (e.g., among family members and with significant others) as well as in public settings (e.g., at work and in school); (3) Expanded use of English did not co-occur with a pattern of Spanish language attrition, but rather occurred alongside the maintenance of high levels of Spanish proficiency as well as intergenerational continuity in the ways that the sounds and structures of Spanish are produced; (4) Within the broader context of intergenerational maintenance of Spanish proficiency and stability in linguistic structure, evidence of linguistic change did emerge along several micro-linguistic dimensions, including subtle but statistically significant changes in the acoustic profiles of certain speech sounds as well as in rates and patterns of use of certain words and linguistic forms; (5) The intergenerational differences that emerged from the data provide further evidence that situations of linguistic contact can promote linguistic change; in this case the observed changes are likely the result of two factors: (i) the regular linguistic interaction of Spanish speakers with varying ancestries/geographic origins, and (ii) increased use of English among Spanish-speaking Bostonians. Together, these factors have promoted small but measurable changes, reducing regionally based differences in the ways that Spanish is spoken in Boston while also increasingly aligning some aspects of Spanish with parallel structures in English.

4. Future research

The study succeeded in answering its primary questions. The data generated by this research initiative are, however, far from being exhaustively analyzed. It is very likely that further analysis of the data collected for this project will yield additional insights into the status of Spanish in the United States as well as the dynamics of language contact, maintenance, and change. In addition to further research led by the project’s primary investigator, the study’s data will also be shared with other qualified research teams in the future, further expanding the long-term impacts of the project.
